In Aldous Huxley’s  Island  (1962), Dr. Robert MacPhail, whose grandfather immigrated to the Kingdom of Pala located in the Polynesian islands, mends the people under his care, mentally and physically. Dr. Robert helps to administer moksha, or a local medicinal psychedelic drug (comparable to mescaline or mushrooms or LSD) for its phsychosomatic healing properties. After the cynical protagonist, Will, of this novel takes the wonder drug at the climax of the narrative, he has a life-changing experience and declares, “believe it or not, but now I can understand what they mean when they say ‘god is love’. What manifest nonsense. Yet it happens to be true.” For evidence that the Beatles were aware of Huxley’s writings on LSD, look no further than the Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Heartclub Band 



 (1967) collage, which includes a photo cut-out of the older 60s-era Huxley.

This could even refer to Doctor Robert MacPhail#cite_note-1), a fictional character in Island, the last book by noted LSD advocate Aldous Huxley.



One of the main themes of the novel is drug use for enlightenment and self-knowledge.

The culture of Pala is the offspring of a Scottish secular humanist medical doctor (Doctor Robert), who made a medical visit to the island in the 19th century and decided to stay and work with its Raja, who embodies the island’s Mahayana Buddhist tradition, to create a society that merges the best of East and West. The Old Raja’s treatise, Notes on What’s What, is a book within the book that explains Pala’s philosophical foundations.



The Beatles‘ story is inextricably linked with drugs. From their early pre-fame days on Benzedrine and Preludin, to the flower-power era of LSD, and onto harder drugs as the 1960s ended.

This could be about Doctor Robert Freymann, a Speed Doctor in New York who supplied many celebrities with drugs.



Reportedly, Dr. Freymann, treated patients with injects of amphetamine-spiked vitamin B-12 from his Manhattan East 78th Street clinic.

It should be noted that most Americans, due to diet and convenience culture, suffer from a vitamin B deficiency, and so an infusion of B vitamins feels like a pick me up all by itself, which is why many popular energy drinks (Red Bull, Monster, etc.) have this in the ingredients.

However, both John and Paul deny going to this specific doctor. In an interview with Barry Miles, Paul said that they just found the idea of the Doctor humorous.

John and I thought it was a funny idea: the fantasy doctor who would fix you up by giving you drugs, [the song] was a parody on that idea. It’s just a piss-take.

There are several theories about the identity of Dr. Robert.  Paul McCartney indicated that Dr. Robert was a New York doctor who was widely known to prescribe drugs to celebrities.

In a later interview, however, Lennon said that, in a way, he was Doctor Robert, claiming he was the one who often kept the band’s supply of drugs.
